heritage|cultural]] or [[natural heritage]] as described in the UNESCO World Heritage Convention, established in 1972.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/convention/|title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre – The World Heritage Convention|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|accessdate=25 October 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160827065310/http://whc.unesco.org/en/convention/|archive-date=27 August 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] inherited the former country of [[Yugoslavia]]'s accession to the convention on 12 July 1993 as one of the successor states.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/ba|title=Bosnia and Herzegovina|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|accessdate=25 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170803110624/http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/ba|archive-date=3 August 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} {{As of|2018}}, there are three sites in Bosnia and Herzegovina on the list and a further nine on the tentative list (the official list of sites that may be considered for future submission). The first site, the [[Stari Most|Old Bridge Area of the Old City of Mostar]], was inscribed to the list at the 29th UNESCO session in 2005.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/946|title=Old Bridge Area of the Old City of Mostar – UNESCO World Heritage Centre|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|accessdate=25 December 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171228224325/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/946/|archive-date=28 December 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} In 1993, during the [[Bosnian War]], it was destroyed by the [[Croatian Defence Council]] in an artillery barrage. It was reconstructed after the conflict and reopened in 2004. In 2007, the [[Mehmed Paša Sokolović Bridge]] in [[Višegrad]] was inscribed to the list.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1260 |title=Mehmed Paša Sokolović Bridge in Višegrad – UNESCO World Heritage Centre |publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre |accessdate=25 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171227011804/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1260 |archive-date=27 December 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} This was followed by the inscription of the [[Stećci Medieval Tombstones Graveyards]] in 2016. The latter is a transnational site, which is also partly in Croatia, Serbia, and Montenegro. Out of 28 listed Stećci sites, 20 are located in Bosnia and Herzegovina, with the most prominent one in [[Radimlja]].{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1504 |title=Stećci Medieval Tombstone Graveyards – UNESCO World Heritage Centre |publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre |accessdate=25 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170917064538/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1504 |archive-date=17 September 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} ==World Heritage sites== UNESCO lists sites under [[World Heritage site#Selection criteria|ten criteria]]; each entry must meet at least one of the criteria. Criteria i through vi are cultural, whereas vii through x are natural.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria/|title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre – The Criteria for Selection|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|accessdate=17 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160612152223/http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria/|archive-date=12 June 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} {{Legend|#D0E7FF|* Transnational site|outline=silver}} {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- ! style="width:180px;" scope="col"| Site ! class="unsortable" style="width:150px;" scope="col"| Image ! style="width:100px;" scope="col"| Location ([[Municipalities of Bosnia and Herzegovina|municipality]]) ! style="width:50px;" scope="col"| Year listed ! style="width:80px;" scope="col"| {{Abbr|UNESCO data|UNESCO reference number and criteria}} ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- ! scope="row"| [[Stari Most|Old Bridge Area of the Old City of Mostar]] | [[File:Stari Most22.jpg|Stari Most|150px]] | [[Mostar]] | align=center| 2005 | 946; vi
(cultural) | This site encompasses the Old Bridge and the surrounding area. The [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] bridge, which crosses the [[Neretva]] river, was commissioned by [[Suleiman the Magnificent]] and completed in 1566/67. In 1993, during the [[Bosnian War]], it was deliberately shelled and destroyed by the [[Croatian Defence Council]]. After the war, the bridge was rebuilt using traditional construction methods and local materials, and reopened in 2004. |- ! scope="row"| [[Mehmed Paša Sokolović Bridge]] | [[File:Visegrad Drina Bridge 1.jpg|Mehmed Paša Sokolović Bridge|150px]] | [[Višegrad]] | align=center| 2007 | 1260; ii, iv
(cultural) | The Mehmed Paša Sokolović Bridge, which crosses the [[Drina]] river, was completed in 1577 by the Ottoman court architect [[Mimar Sinan]] on the orders of the [[Grand Vizier]] [[Mehmed Paša Sokolović]]. |- ! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| [[Stećak|Stećci Medieval Tombstones Graveyards]]* | [[File:BiH, Radimlja necropolis 5.jpg|Radimlja necropolis|150px]] | 20 sites | align=center| 2016 | 1504; iii, vi
(cultural) | Stećci ({{abbr|sing.|singular}} stećak) are the monolith medieval tombstones found in modern-day Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as parts of Croatia, Serbia, and Montenegro. They first appeared in the 12th century and reached their peak in the 14th and 15th centuries. There are 20 sites in Bosnia and Herzegovina, mostly in the southeastern part of the country. The largest cluster is located in [[Radimlja]], in the [[Stolac]] municipality. |} ==Tentative list== In addition to the sites inscribed on the World Heritage list, member states can maintain a list of tentative sites that they may consider for nomination. Nominations for the World Heritage list are only accepted if the site was previously listed on the tentative list.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists|title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre – Tentative Lists|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|accessdate=25 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170720204834/http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/|archive-date=20 July 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} As of 2018, Bosnia and Herzegovina recorded nine sites on its tentative list.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/state=ba|title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre – Tentative Lists: Bosnia and Herzegovina|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|accessdate=25 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170716223857/http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/state=ba|archive-date=16 July 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- ! style="width:180px;" scope="col"| Site ! class="unsortable" style="width:150px;" scope="col"| Image ! style="width:100px;" scope="col"| Location ([[Municipalities of Bosnia and Herzegovina|municipality]]) ! style="width:50px;" scope="col" | Year listed ! style="width:80px;" scope="col"| UNESCO criteria ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- ! scope="row"| [[Sarajevo]] – unique symbol of universal multiculture – continual open city (N.I.) | [[File:Sarajevo City Panorama.JPG|Sarajevo|150px]] | Sarajevo | align=center| 1997 | v
(cultural) | Sarajevo, the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina, has a long and rich history of religious and cultural diversity.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/906/ |title=Sarajevo – unique symbol of universal multiculture – continual open city (N.I.) – UNESCO World Heritage Centre |publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre |accessdate=25 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180110162517/http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/906/ |archive-date=10 January 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} |- ! scope="row"| [[Vjetrenica|Vjetrenica cave]] | [[File:Vjetrenica Cave.JPG|Vjetrenica|150px]] | [[Ravno, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Ravno]] | align=center| 2004 | vii, x
(natural) | Vjetrenica (meaning "the wind cave") is the largest cave in Bosnia and Herzegovina. In the warmer parts of the year, cold air blows from its entrance. It is an important biodiversity spot. Fossils of prehistoric carnivores have been found in the cave.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/1975/ |title=Vjetrenica cave – UNESCO World Heritage Centre |publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre |accessdate=25 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180110145256/http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/1975/ |archive-date=10 January 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} |- ! scope="row" data-sort-value="Jajce"| The natural and architectural ensemble of [[Jajce]] | [[File:Vodopad u Jajcu.jpg|Jajce|150px]] | Jajce | align=center| 2006 | ii, iii, iv, v, vi, vii
(mixed) | The city of Jajce is located at the confluence of the [[Pliva]] and [[Vrbas (river)|Vrbas]] rivers. It was founded in the [[Middle Ages]] and acquired its final form during the Ottoman period.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/2098/ |title=The natural and architectural ensemble of Jajce – UNESCO World Heritage Centre |publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre |accessdate=25 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180110160709/http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/2098/ |archive-date=10 January 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} |- ! scope="row" data-sort-value="Počitelj"| The historic urban site of [[Počitelj, Čapljina|Počitelj]] | [[File:Počitelj - pano.jpg|Počitelj|150px]] | [[Čapljina]] | align=center| 2007 | ii, iii, iv, v, vi
(cultural) | The city of Počitelj presents one of the few urban ensembles in Bosnia and Herzegovina preserved in their integrity from the medieval and Ottoman periods.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5092/ |title=The historic urban site of Počitelj – UNESCO World Heritage Centre |publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre |accessdate=25 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171217085333/http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5092 |archive-date=17 December 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} |- ! scope="row" data-sort-value="Blagaj"| The natural and architectural ensemble of [[Blagaj]] | [[File:Blagaj 1.jpg|Blagaj|150px]] | Mostar | align=center| 2007 | ii, iii, iv, v, vi, vii
(mixed) | The town of Blagaj, situated at the spring of the [[Buna (Neretva)|Buna]] river, contains several examples of Ottoman architecture, such as the [[Vrelo Bune|Blagaj Tekke]].{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5280/ |title=The natural and architectural ensemble of Blagaj – UNESCO World Heritage Centre |publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre |accessdate=25 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100217183143/http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5280 |archive-date=17 February 2010 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} |- ! scope="row" data-sort-value="Blidinje"| The natural and architectural ensemble of [[Blidinje]] | [[File:Blidinjsko jezero (23 ha, hl. max. 3,5 m) z Maleho Vranu.jpg|Blidinjsko jezero|150px]] | [[Jablanica, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Jablanica]], [[Posušje]], [[Tomislavgrad]] | align=center| 2007 | i, iii, iv, v, vi, vii, viii, ix
(mixed) | The Blidinje Nature Park area is an example of the geological processes that took place during the [[orogenesis]] of the [[Dinarides]], as well as an example of the evolutionary development of postglacial flora and fauna. The area features a wide range of endemic plant communities and contains several stećak tombstones.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5281/ |title=The natural and architectural ensemble of Blidinje – UNESCO World Heritage Centre |publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre |accessdate=25 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180110145723/http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5281/ |archive-date=10 January 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} |- ! scope="row" data-sort-value="Stolac"| The natural and architectural ensemble of [[Stolac]] | [[File:Stolac.jpg|Stolac|150px]] | Stolac | align=center| 2007 | ii, iii, iv, v, vi, vii
(mixed) | The historic core of Stolac is an example of a complex cultural-historical and natural environmental ensemble. The area contains remains from prehistory, the [[Illyrians|Illyrian]]-[[Roman Empire|Roman]] era, the Middle Ages, and the Ottoman, [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian]], and [[Yugoslavia|Yugoslav]] periods.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5282/ |title=The natural and architectural ensemble of Stolac – UNESCO World Heritage Centre |publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre |accessdate=25 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171115055218/http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5282 |archive-date=15 November 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} |- ! scope="row"| Strict Nature Reserve – Primeval forest "[[Perućica]]" | [[File:Skakavac-Perucica-NP Sutjeska.JPG|Perućica|150px]] | [[Foča]] | align=center| 2017 | vii, ix, x
(natural) | The primeval forest of Perućica is an important biodiversity spot, home to [[brown bear]], [[wolf]], and [[lynx]], as well as to several species of birds, reptiles, and amphibians. Its mountain creek forms the {{convert|75|m|abbr=on}} high [[Skakavac Waterfall, Perućica|Skakavac Waterfall]].{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/6260/ |title=Strict Nature Reserve – Primeval forest “Perućica” – UNESCO World Heritage Centre |publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre |accessdate=25 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170920122120/http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/6260/ |archive-date=20 September 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} |- ! scope="row"| [[Old Jewish Cemetery, Sarajevo|Jewish Cemetery in Sarajevo]] | [[File:Sarajevo Jevrejsko groblje 6.jpg|Jewish Cemetery in Sarajevo|150px]] | Sarajevo | align=center| 2018 | ii, iii, iv, vi
(cultural) |The burial complex lies on a steep site and covers a total area of {{convert|31,160|m2|sqft|abbr=on}}. There are more than 3,850 tombstones in a total of seven plots, along with four memorials erected to the victims of [[World War II]] fascist terror and several [[cenotaph]]s. The complex also includes a large [[Ashkenazi]] [[ossuary]] built in 1962 following the exhumation of the old and the new Ashkenazi graveyards. In 1966, the cemetery was closed for burials. It is believed that the ''[[Geniza]]'' (a graveyard for worn out books) is located in the southeastern part of the cemetery.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/6334/|title=Jewish Cemetery in Sarajevo – UNESCO World Heritage Centre|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|accessdate=3 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180703050943/http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/6334/|archive-date=3 July 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} |} ==See also== *[[List of National Monuments of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] == References== {{Reflist}} {{World Heritage Sites in Bosnia and Herzegovina}} {{National Monuments of Bosnia and Herzegovina}} {{Bosnia and Herzegovina topics}} {{Lists of World Heritage Sites in Europe}} {{featured list}} [[Category:World Heritage Sites in Bosnia and Herzegovina]] [[Category:National Monuments of Bosnia and Herzegovina|*]] [[Category:Bosnia and Herzegovina-related lists|w]] [[Category:Bosnia and Herzegovina history-related lists|w]] [[Category:Bosnia and Herzegovina heritage-related lists|w]] [[Category:Bosnia and Herzegovina geography-related lists|w]] [[Category:Lists of World Heritage Sites|Bosnia and Herzegovina]] [[Category:World Heritage Tentative List by Bosnia and Herzegovina]] [[Category:Lists of tourist attractions in Bosnia and Herzegovina|World Heritage Sites]]

page.title: List of World Heritage sites in Croatia

revision.text:
{{Location map+|Croatia|width=320|float=right|caption=World Heritage sites in Croatia
yellow = Cultural, green = Natural |places= {{Location map~|Croatia|lat=42.640585|long=18.109007|region=HR-19|position=9|mark=yellow_pog.svg||label=[[Dubrovnik]] |name= Old City of Dubrovnik}} {{Location map~|Croatia|lat=43.508716|long=16.439049|region=HR-17|position=bottom|mark=yellow_pog.svg|label= [[Split, Croatia|Split]] |name= Historical Complex of Split with the Palace of Diocletian}} {{Location map~|Croatia|lat=44.877780|long=15.614440|region=HR-04|position=top|mark=green_pog.svg|label= [[Plitvice Lakes National Park|Plitvice]] |name= Plitvice Lakes National Park}} {{Location map~|Croatia|lat=45.228739|long=13.592882|region=HR-18|position=12|mark=yellow_pog.svg|label= [[Poreč]] |name= Episcopal Complex of the Euphrasian Basilica in the Historic Centre of Poreč}} {{Location map~|Croatia|lat=43.516538|long=16.249878|region=HR-17|position=left|mark=yellow_pog.svg|label= [[Trogir]] |name= Historic city of Trogir}} {{Location map~|Croatia|lat=43.73566|long=15.88909|region=HR-15|position=2|mark=yellow_pog.svg|label= [[Šibenik]] |name= Šibenik: Cathedral of Saint James and St. Nicholas Fortress}} {{Location map~|Croatia|lat=43.181667|long=16.638611|region=HR-17|position=bottom|mark=yellow_pog.svg|label= [[Stari Grad Plain]] |name= Stari Grad Plain}} {{Location map~|Croatia|lat=43.515356|long=16.927194|region=HR-17|position=3|mark=yellow_pog.svg|marksize= 6|label= Stećci - Cista Velika|name= Stećci- Cista Velika }} {{Location map~|Croatia|lat=42.541783|long=18.422381|region=HR-17|position=bottom|mark=yellow_pog.svg|marksize= 6|label= Stećci - Dubravka|name= Stećci-Dubravka}} {{Location map~|Croatia|lat=44.343489|long=15.485149|region=HR-13|position=2|mark=green_pog.svg|marksize= 6|label= [[Paklenica]] |name= Paklenica}} {{Location map~|Croatia|lat=44.711531|long=14.978472|region=HR-09|position=3|mark=green_pog.svg|marksize= 6|label= [[Northern Velebit National Park |Velebit]] |name= Northern Velebit National Park }} {{Location map~|Croatia|lat=44.115350|long= 15.225172|region=HR-13|position=9|mark=yellow_pog.svg|marksize= 6|label= [[Zadar]] |name= Defensive System of Zadar }} }} The [[UNESCO|United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization]] (UNESCO) [[World Heritage site]]s are places of importance to [[cultural heritage|cultural]] or [[natural heritage]] as described in the UNESCO World Heritage Convention, established in 1972.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/convention/|title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre – The World Heritage Convention|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|date=25 October 2015}} [[Croatia]], following its [[Independence of Croatia|declaration of independence]] from [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] on 25 June 1991, succeeded the convention on 6 July 1992.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/hr|title=Croatia|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|date=25 July 2017}} Currently, there are ten sites inscribed on the list and 15 sites on the tentative list. The first three sites, [[Historical Complex of Split with the Palace of Diocletian]], [[Dubrovnik]], and [[Plitvice Lakes National Park]], were inscribed to the list at the 3rd UNESCO session in 1979. Further sites were added in 1997, 2000, 2008, 2016, and 2017. In total, there are eight cultural and two natural sites, as determined by the organization's [[World Heritage site#Selection criteria|selection criteria]]. Three of the sites are shared with other countries. During the [[Croatian War of Independence]], following the [[breakup of Yugoslavia]], military confrontations took place in Dubrovnik ([[Siege of Dubrovnik]]) and in the Plitvice Lakes area. Extensive artillery damage in Dubrovnik and landmines laid around Plitvice resulted in the two sites being listed as [[List of World Heritage in Danger|endangered]] in 1991. Following their restoration, Plitvice and Dubrovnik were removed from the list of endangered sites in 1997 and 1998, respectively.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/1997/whc-97-conf208-17e.pdf |title=World Heritage Committee: Twenty-first session |publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|format=PDF |accessdate=14 November 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/1998/whc-98-conf203-18e.pdf |title=World Heritage Committee: Twenty-first session|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org |format=PDF |date= 14 November 2017}} Although Croatia's World Heritage sites generate large numbers of visitors, new threats are emerging due to the detrimental effects of uncontrolled mass tourism.{{cite web|author=Sven Milekic, Dusica Tomovic, Sinisa Jakov Marusic |url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/uncontrolled-tourism-threatens-balkan-unesco-sites-04-13-2017 |title=Uncontrolled Tourism Threatens Balkan UNESCO Sites |publisher=Balkan Insight |accessdate=14 November 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/soc/3616 |title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre - State of Conservation (SOC 2017) Plitvice Lakes National Park (Croatia) |publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org |accessdate=14 November 2017}} ==World Heritage sites== UNESCO lists sites under [[World Heritage site#Selection criteria|ten criteria]]; each entry must meet at least one of the criteria. Criteria i through vi are cultural, whereas vii through x are natural.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria/|title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre – The Criteria for Selection|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre |accessdate=17 August 2018}} {{Legend|#D0E7FF|* Transnational site|outline=silver}} {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- ! style="width:180px;" scope="col"| Site ! class="unsortable" style="width:150px;" scope="col"| Image ! style="width:100px;" scope="col"| Location ! style="width:50px;" scope="col"| Year listed ! style="width:80px;" scope="col" data-sort-type="number"| {{Abbr|UNESCO data|UNESCO reference number and criteria}} ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- ! scope="row"| [[Plitvice Lakes National Park]] | [[File:Plitvice-2003.JPG|150px]] | [[Plitvička Jezera]] | align=center| 1979 | 98; vii, viii, ix (natural) | Over time, water has flown over the natural [[limestone]] and chalk, creating natural dams which in turn have created a series of connecting lakes, waterfalls, and caves. The nearby forests are home to bears, wolves, and many rare bird species.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/98|title=Plitvice Lakes National Park|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row" | Historical Complex of [[Split (city)|Split]] with the [[Diocletian's Palace|Palace of Diocletian]] | [[File:Peristyle of Diocletian's Palace, Split (11908116224).jpg|150px]] | Split | align=center| 1979 | 97; ii, iii, iv (cultural) | The palace was built by the [[Roman emperor]] [[Diocletian]] at the turn of the fourth century AD, and later served as the basis of the city of Split. A cathedral was built in the Middle Ages inside the ancient mausoleum, along with churches, fortifications, Gothic and Renaissance palaces. The Baroque style makes up the rest of the area.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/97|title=Historical Complex of Split with the Palace of Diocletian|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row" | Old City of [[Dubrovnik]] | [[File:Dubra.JPG|150px]] | Dubrovnik | align=center| 1979 | 95; i, iii, iv (cultural) | Dubrovnik became a prosperous [[Maritime Republics|Maritime Republic]] during the [[Middle Ages]], it became the only eastern Adriatic [[city-state]] to rival [[Venice]]. Supported by its wealth and skilled [[diplomacy]], the city achieved a remarkable level of development, particularly during the 15th and 16th centuries.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/95|title=Old City of Dubrovnik|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row" | Episcopal Complex of the [[Euphrasian Basilica]] in the Historic Centre of [[Poreč]] | [[File:Croatia Porec Euphrasius Basilika BW 2014-10-08 10-44-45.jpg|150px]] | Poreč | align=center| 1997 | 809; ii, iv (cultural) | The episcopal complex, with its striking mosaics dating back to the 6th century, is one of the best examples of early [[Byzantine art]] and architecture in the Mediterranean region and the world. It includes the basilica itself, a sacristy, a baptistery, and the bell tower of the nearby archbishop's palace.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/809|title=Episcopal Complex of the Euphrasian Basilica in the Historic Centre of Poreč|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row" | Historic city of [[Trogir]] | [[File:Trogir Skyline.JPG|150px]] | Trogir | align=center| 1997 | 810; ii, iv (cultural) | Trogir's rich culture was created under the influence of old Greeks, Romans, and Venetians. It is the best-preserved Romanesque-Gothic complex not only in the [[Adriatic]], but in all of [[Central Europe]]. Trogir's [[medieval]] core, surrounded by walls, comprises a preserved castle and tower and a series of dwellings and palaces from the Romanesque, Gothic, Renaissance, and Baroque periods.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/810|title=Historic City of Trogir|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Cathedral of St. James, Šibenik|Cathedral of Saint James]] | [[File:St. Jacobuskathedraal ; Sibenik.jpg|150px]] | [[Šibenik]] | align=center| 2000 | 963; i, ii, iv (cultural) | The cathedral is a triple-nave [[basilica]] with three apses and a dome ({{convert|32|m|ft}} high inside) and is also one of the most important [[Renaissance]] architectural monuments in the eastern Adriatic.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/963|title=The Cathedral of St James in Šibenik|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Stari Grad Plain]] | [[File:Starigradsko polje hvar.jpg|150px]] | [[Hvar]] | align=center| 2008 | 1240; ii, iii, v (cultural) | The Stari Grad Plain is an agricultural landscape that was set up by the [[colonies in antiquity|ancient Greek colonists]] in the 4th century BC, and remains in use today. The plain is generally still in its original form. The ancient layout has been preserved by careful maintenance of the stone walls over 24 centuries.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1240|title=Stari Grad Plain|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| [[Stećci Medieval Tombstones Graveyards]]* | [[File:Mramorje 2.JPG|150px]] | Dubravka, [[Cista Provo|Cista Velika]] | align=center| 2016 | 1504; iii, vi (cultural) | Stećci (sing. stećak) or the medieval tombstones are the monolith stone monuments found in the regions of the present Bosnia and Herzegovina, parts of Croatia, Serbia, and Montenegro. They first appeared in the 12th century and reached their peak in the 14th and 15th century. There are two sites inscribed in Croatia, in Dubravka and in Cista Velika.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1504|title=Stećci Medieval Tombstones Graveyards|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| [[Venetian Works of Defence between 15th and 17th centuries: Stato da Terra – western Stato da Mar|Venetian Works of defence between 15th and 17th centuries]]* | [[File:Zadar fortification.jpg|150px]] | [[Zadar]], Šibenik | align=center| 2017 | 1533; iii, iv (cultural) |This property consists of 15 components of defence works in Italy, Croatia, and Montenegro, spanning more than 1,000 kilometres between the Lombard region of Italy and the eastern Adriatic Coast. The introduction of gunpowder led to significant shifts in military techniques and architecture. Croatian sites include the defensive system of Zadar and [[St. Nicholas Fortress]] in Šibenik.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1533|title=Venetian Works of Defence between the 16th and 17th Centuries: Stato da Terra – Western Stato da Mar|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| [[Primeval Beech Forests of the Carpathians and Other Regions of Europe]]* | [[File:Paklenica Buljma.jpg|150px]] | [[Paklenica]], [[Northern Velebit National Park]] | align=center| 2017 | 1133; ix (natural) | This transboundary site (shared with Albania, Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Germany, Italy, Poland, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, and Ukraine) encompasses the isolated refuges from which the [[European beech]] has spread across the continent since the end of the last Ice Age. This successful expansion is related to the tree’s flexibility and tolerance of different climatic, geographical and physical conditions.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1133|title=Ancient and Primeval Beech Forests of the Carpathians and Other Regions of Europe|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |} ==Tentative list== In addition to the sites inscribed on the World Heritage list, member states can maintain a list of tentative sites that they may consider for nomination. Nominations for the World Heritage list are only accepted if the site was previously listed on the tentative list.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists|title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre – Tentative Lists|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=25 July 2017}} As of 2017, Croatia recorded fifteen sites on its tentative list, all added in the years 2005 and 2007.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/state=hr|title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre – Tentative Lists: Croatia|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=25 July 2017}} {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- ! style="width:180px;" scope="col"| Site ! class="unsortable" style="width:150px;" scope="col"| Image ! style="width:100px;" scope="col"| Location ! style="width:50px;" scope="col" | Year listed ! style="width:80px;" scope="col"| UNESCO criteria ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- ! scope="row"| [[Zadar]] – Episcopal complex | [[File:Kathedrale St. Anastasia.jpg|150px]] | [[Zadar County]] | align=center| 2005 | i, ii, iii, iv, vi (cultural) | The site encompasses the Romanesque [[Zadar Cathedral]], [[Church of St. Donatus]] from the 9th century, the archbishop’s palace, and other buildings. Originally a [[Liburnian]] settlement and later a Roman colony, Zadar still preserves its Roman forum and street plan.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/157|title=Zadar – Episcopal complex|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| Historical-town planning ensemble of [[Ston]] with Mali Ston, [[Walls of Ston|connecting walls]], the Mali Ston Bay nature reserve, Stonsko Polje and the salt pans | [[File:Mali Ston-04.jpg|150px]] | [[Dubrovnik-Neretva County]] | align=center| 2005 | i, iii, iv, v (cultural) | Ston was a major fort of the [[Republic of Ragusa]]. The area of this cultural property includes urban ensembles developed in accordance with the configuration of the ground and the preserved parts of the outstanding natural environment.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/160|title=Historical-town planning ensemble of Ston with Mali Ston, connecting walls, the Mali Ston Bay nature reserve, Stonsko Polje and the salt pans|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| Historical-Town Planning Ensemble [[Tvrđa]] (Fort) in [[Osijek]] | [[File:Osijek (tvrđa).JPG|150px]] | [[Osijek-Baranja County]] | align=center| 2005 | i, iv, vi (cultural) | Tvrđa, a [[Habsburg]] [[star fort]], contains the best-preserved and largest ensemble of Baroque buildings in Croatia and has been described as a unique example of an 18th-century baroque military, administrative, and commercial urban center.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/161|title=Historical-Town Planning Ensemble Tvrda (Fort) in Osijek|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Varaždin]] – Historic Nucleus and Old Town (the Castle) | [[File:Stari grad Varaždin.JPG|150px]] | [[Varaždin County]] | align=center| 2005 | i, iii, iv, vi (cultural) | The city nucleus represents an ensemble of medieval-renaissance-baroque buildings. For a brief period in the 18th century, Varaždin was the capital of Croatia.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/162|title=Varazdin – Historic Nucleus and Old Town (the Castle)|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Veliki Tabor Castle|Burg – Castle of Veliki Tabor]] | [[File:Veliki Tabor.JPG|150px]] | [[Krapina-Zagorje County]] | align=center| 2005 | iv (cultural) | The castle, built in the 15th and 16th centuries, combines features of late Gothic and Renaissance architecture.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/1167|title=Burg – Castle of Veliki Tabor|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Lonjsko Polje|Lonjsko Polje Nature Park]] | [[File:Konji (Lonjsko Polje).jpg|150px]] | [[Sisak-Moslavina County]] | align=center| 2005 | (mixed) | The largest protected [[wetland]] in the [[Danube basin]] is an important habitat for birds and other animals. Large pasture lands have remained preserved to the present for indigenous livestock species found in this region.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/2012|title=Lonjsko Polje|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Velebit|Velebit Mountain]] | [[File:Paklenica3.jpg|150px]] | [[Lika-Senj County]] and [[Zadar County]] | align=center| 2005 | vii, viii, ix, x (natural) | The largest mountain massive in Croatia, exhibiting a wide range of [[karst]] landforms.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/2013|title=Velebit Mountain|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| Frontiers of the Roman Empire Croatian Limes | align=center| – | [[Osijek-Baranja County]] and [[Vukovar-Srijem County]] | align=center| 2005 | i, ii, iii, iv, v (cultural) | The Croatian part of the [[Danubian Limes]] stretches from Batina Skela to [[Ilok]] and is {{convert|188|km|mi}} long. This section of the border was secured by forts and watchtowers, connected by military roads.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/2014|title=Frontiers of the Roman Empire Croatian Limes|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Diocletian's Palace]] and the Historical Nucleus of [[Split, Croatia|Split]] (extension) | [[File:Diocletian's Palace from the air.jpg|frameless|150x150px]] | [[Split-Dalmatia County]] | align=center| 2005 | i, ii, iii, iv, v (cultural) | Extension to the existing World Heritage site, to include additional sites, including the Diocletian Aqueduct.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/2015|title=Diocletian's Palace and the Historical Nucleus of Split (extension)|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Lubenice]] | [[File:Lubenice-Cres1.jpg|150px]] | [[Primorje-Gorski Kotar County]] | align=center| 2005 | v (cultural) | A village at a strategic location on the island of [[Cres]], inhabited since the prehistoric era.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/2017|title=Lubenice|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Primošten]] Vineyards | align=center| – | [[Šibenik-Knin County]] | align=center| 2007 | v, vi (cultural) | The Primošten vineyards represent a materialized traditional form of cultivating a specific kind of Mediterranean soil.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5102|title=Primošten Vineyards|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Blaca hermitage|Hermitage Blaca]] | [[File:Blaca.jpg|150px]] | [[Split-Dalmatia County]] | align=center| 2007 | ii, v (cultural) | The hermitage established in the 16th century by [[Glagolitic script|Glagolitic]] monks.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5103 |title=Hermitage Blaca|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Motovun|City of Motovun]] | [[File:Motovun – General view - 01.jpg|150px]] | [[Istria County]] | align=center| 2007 | ii, iv (cultural) | A medieval town, developed from a prehistoric hill fort, that has preserved its medieval characteristics.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5104|title=City of Motovun|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Korčula (town)|The historic town of Korčula]] | [[File:Korcula City.jpg|150px]] | [[Dubrovnik-Neretva County]] | align=center| 2007 | ii, iii, iv, v (cultural) | A historic fortified town on the protected east coast of the island of [[Korčula]].{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5105|title=The historic town of Korčula|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Kornati|Kornati National Park]] and [[Telašćica]] Nature Park | [[File:Kornati.jpg|150px]] | [[Šibenik-Knin County]] and [[Zadar County]] | align=center| 2007 | vii, viii, x (natural) | An isolated archipelago, exhibiting a wide range of Karst landforms, and an important protected area for marine wildlife.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5106|title=Kornati National Park and Telašćica Nature Park|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}} |} ==See also== *[[Register of Protected Natural Values of Croatia]] *[[Register of Cultural Goods of Croatia]] *[[UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list World Heritage List] {{Croatia topics}} {{Lists of World Heritage Sites in Europe}} {{World Heritage Sites in Croatia}} {{featured list}} [[Category:World Heritage Sites in Croatia| ]] [[Category:Croatia geography-related lists|World Heritage Sites]] [[Category:Lists of World Heritage Sites|Croatia]] [[Category:Lists of buildings and structures in Croatia|World Heritage Sites]] [[Category:Lists of tourist attractions in Croatia|World Heritage Sites]]

page.title: List of books featured on Book of the Week in 2012

revision.comment: Removing link(s) to "Carmen Bugan": no article. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of books featured on ''Book of the Week'' in 2012}} {{for|other years|List of books featured on Book of the Week}} This is a list of books which have been featured on [[BBC Radio 4]]'s ''[[Book of the Week]]'' during 2012.
== January == * 02-06 ''Looking for Transwonderland'' by [[Noo Saro-Wiwa]], read by [[Janice Acquah]]. The next five days featured a series of essays ''Stop What You're Doing and Read This'' comprising * 09 – ''Memories and Expectations'' by [[Michael Rosen]], read by the author. * 10 – ''A Bed. A Book. A Mountain'' by [[Jeanette Winterson]], read by the author. * 11 – ''Mindful Reading'' by [[Tim Parks]], read by the author. * 12 – ''True Daemons'' by [[Carmen Callil]], read by the author. * 13 – ''The Right Words in the Right Order'' by [[Mark Haddon]], read by the author. * 16–20 – ''[[El Narco]]'' by [[Ioan Grillo]], read by [[Rupert Degas]]. * 23–27 – ''A Shed of One's Own: Midlife without the Crisis'' by [[Marcus Berkmann]], read by [[Toby Longworth]].
== February == * 30-03 – ''The Train in the Night: A Story of Music and Loss'' by [[Nick Coleman (British writer)|Nick Coleman]], read by [[Sean Foley (director)|Sean Foley]] * 06-10 – ''A Card from Angela Carter'' by [[Susannah Clapp]], read by the author and [[Claire Skinner]]. * 13–17 – ''Europe in the Looking Glass'' by [[Robert Byron]], read by [[Rupert Penry-Jones]]. * 20–24 – ''What the Grown-Ups Were Doing'' by [[Michelle Hanson]], read by [[Rebecca Front]].
== March == * 27-02 – ''Wilkie Collins'' by [[Peter Ackroyd]], read by [[Michael Pennington]]. * 05-09 – ''Then They Came for Me'' by [[Maziar Bahari]], read by [[Phlip Arditti]] and [[Peter Hamilton Dyer]]. * 12–16 – ''20 Letters to a Friend'' by [[Svetlana Alliluyeva]], read by [[Stella Gonet]]. * 19–23 – ''Land's Edge – A Coastal Memoir'' by [[Tim Winton]], read by [[Stephen Dillane]]. * 26–30 – ''Escape from Camp 14'' by [[Blaine Harden]], read by [[Kerry Shale]].
== April == * 02-06 – ''The Great Animal Orchestra'' by [[Bernie Krause]], read by [[Nigel Lindsay]]. * 09-13 – ''Double Cross'' by [[Ben Macintyre]], read by [[Jonathan Keeble]]. * 16–20 – ''Besieged: Life Under Fire in a Sarajevo Street'' by [[Barbara Demick]], read by [[Laurel Lefkow]]. * 23–27 – ''Sightlines'' by [[Kathleen Jamie]], read by [[Maureen Beattie]].
== May == * 29-04 – ''The Man within My Head'' by [[Pico Iyer]], read by [[Paul Basely]]. The next 5 days had a series of shorter fiction under the title ''Granta's Britain'' :* 07 – ''Sugar in the Blood'' by [[Andrea Stuart]], read by [[Lorraine Burroughs]]. :* 08-09 – ''Stevenage'' by [[Gary Younge]], read by [[David Harewood]]. :* 10 – ''Theatre of Fortune' by [[Nikolai Khalezin]] and [[Natalia Kaliada]], read by [[Basher Savage]]. :* 11 – ''The Magic Place'' by [[Kapka Kassabova]], read by the author. * 14–18 – ''The Uke of Wallington'' by [[Mark Wallington (writer)|Mark Wallington]], read by [[Hugh Dennis]]. * 21–25 – ''Hedge Britannia'' by [[Hugh Barker]], read by [[Tim Key]]. * 28–32 – ''Midnight in Peking'' by [[Paul French (author)|Paul French]], read by [[Crawford Logan]].
== June == * 04-08 – ''Strands'' by [[Jean Sprackland]], read by the author. * 11–15 – ''Dear Lupin'' by [[Roger Mortimer (author)|Roger Mortimer]], read by [[David Horovitch]] and [[Nicky Henson]]. * 18–22 – ''Beauty and the Inferno'' by [[Roberto Saviano]], read by [[Nicholas Murchie]]. * 25–29 – ''Damn His Blood'' by [[Peter Moore (author)|Peter Moore]], read by [[Alex Jennings]].
== July == * 02-06 – ''The Old Ways'' by [[Robert Macfarlane (writer)|Robert Macfarlane]], read by [[Dan Stevens]]. * 09-13 – ''The Ecstasy of Influence'' by [[Jonathan Lethem]], read by [[Kerry Shale]]. * 16–20 – ''Burying the Typewriter'' by Carmen Bugan, read by [[Anamaria Marinca]]. * 23–27 – ''Follow the Money'' by [[Steve Boggan]], read by [[Ian Redford (actor)|Ian Redford]].
== August == * 30-03 – ''Behind the Beautiful Forevers'' by [[Katherine Boo]], read by [[Sudha Bhuchar]]. * 06-10 – ''Tubes: Behind the Scenes at the Internet'' by [[Andrew Blum]], read by [[John Schwab]]. * 13–17 – ''Mrs Robinson's Disgrace'' by [[Kate Summerscale]], read by [[Emma Fielding]]. * 20–24 – ''Thinking in Numbers'' by [[Daniel Tammet]], read by [[James Anthony Pearson]]. * 27-01 – ''Leonardo and the Last Supper'' by [[Ross King (author)|Ross King]], read by [[Nigel Anthony]].
== September == * 03-07 – ''Winter Journal'' by [[Paul Auster]], read by [[Garrick Hagon]]. * 10–14 – ''Bring Me Sunshine'' by [[Charlie Connelly]], read by [[Stephen Mangan]]. * 17–21 – ''[[Joseph Anton: A Memoir]]'' by [[Salman Rushdie]], read by [[Zubin Varla]]. * 24–28 – ''Vanished Years'' by [[Rupert Everett]], read by the author.
== October == * 01-05 – ''Country Girl'' by [[Edna O'Brien]], read by the author. * 08-12 – ''On The Map'' by [[Simon Garfield]], read by the author. * 15–19 – ''Nancy: The Story of Lady Astor'' by [[Adrian Fort]], read by [[Anna Maxwell Martin]]. * 22–26 – ''[[Into the Abyss (book)|Into the Abyss]]'' by [[Carol Shaben]], read by [[Barbara Barnes]]. * 29-02 – ''Tombstone'' by [[Yang Jishen]], read by [[David Yip]].
== November == * 05-09 – ''On Wheels'' by [[Michael Holroyd]], read by the author. * 12–16 – ''Former People'' by [[Douglas Smith (author)|Douglas Smith]], read by [[Robert Powell]]. * 19–23 – ''Patrick Leigh Fermor: An Adventure'' by [[Artemis Cooper]], read by [[Samuel West]]. * 26–30 – ''The Black Count'' by [[Tom Reiss]], read by [[Hugh Quarshie]].
== December == * 03-07 – ''[[The Horologicon]]'' by [[Mark Forsyth]], read by [[Hugh Dennis]]. * 10–14 – ''Looking for Mrs Livingstone'' by [[Julie Davidson]], read by [[Tamara Kennedy]]. * 17–21 – ''Shakespeare's Local – Six Centuries of History Seen through One Extraordinary Pub'' by [[Pete Brown (writer)]], read by [[Tony Robinson]]. * 24–28 – ''Three Houses'' by [[Angela Thirkell]], read by [[Sian Thomas]]. * 31-03 – ''Wild'' by [[Cheryl Strayed]], read by [[Kelly Burke]].
{{Book of the Week}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Book of the Week in 2012, List of books featured on}} [[Category:Lists of books]] [[Category:Lists of radio series episodes]] [[Category:British literature-related lists]]

page.title: List of works by Charles-Auguste Lebourg

revision.comment: [[Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]: Copying from [[Category:French sculptors]] to [[Category:French male sculptors]]
revision.text:
[[Charles-Auguste Lebourg]] was a French sculptor born in [[Nantes]] in 1829. He died in Paris in 1906. This is a listing of his main works.
==Main works== These are listed below.
==Paris' Hôtel de ville== In 1881, Lebourg executed an allegory of Nantes as part of the town hall's decoration.<ref name=wkp/>
=="Travail"== Lebourg executed the bronze statue '''"Travail"''' for the École Diderot.<ref name=wkp/> It was shown at the 1885 Paris Salon and the Paris [[Exposition Universelle (1889)]].<ref name=wkp>{{cite web|url=http://www.wikiphidias.fr/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=481:lebourg-charles-auguste&catid=34:biographie&Itemid=53#Synthèse|title=Biographical details|accessdate=23 January 2015}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://leveilleurdenuit.pagesperso-orange.fr/|title=école Diderot|accessdate=23 January 2015}}</ref>
==Bust of Richard Wallace, Fourth Marquess of Hertford and Lady Wallace== [[Image:Charles Lebourg - buste de Mme Wallace.jpg|Bust of Lady Wallace|thumb|centre|200px|Lady Wallace]] In 1872 Lebourg completed a posthumous bust in white marble based on a photograph of the Wallaces by Étienne Corjat of 1855. His white marble bust of Lady Wallace shown here was exhibited at the Paris salon in May 1872.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lisburn.com/books/historical_society/volume8/volume8-8.html |title=Richard Wallace and his wife|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
=="Berger lisant"== [[File:Statue Fontainebleau Charles Le Bourg.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Marble statue "Berger lisant" by Charles-Auguste Lebourg (French sculptor, 1829-1906), in a niche of the wing of the "Galerie des Cerfs", Château de Fontainebleau]] This Lebourg sculpture depicting a shepherd reading stands in the grounds of the [[Château de Fontainebleau]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.statuedefrance.fr/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=92&Itemid=534 |title=Berger lisant|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
==The Louvre== Lebourg has three of his sculptures decorating parts of the outside of the Louvre. The Mollien Pavilion and the Ailes Mollien (an "aile" is a wing) is part of the cour Napoléon and is named after a Treasury minister at the time of the [[French colonial empire|French Empire]] ([[Nicolas François, Count Mollien]]) and Lebourg's '''"La Chasse"''' is one of the group of children decorating what is known as the "aile en retour Mollien". The second of Lebourg's sculptures can be seen in the Richelieu pavilion where the tympanum of the arcade of the passage leading to the rue de Rivoli is decorated with Lebourg's bas relief '''"Vérite et Histoire"'''. The third sculpture, again part of the cour Napoléon, decorates the Apollon rotunda and is entitled '''"La Force"'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://louvre.sculpturederue.fr/index.html |title=Comprehensive and easily navigable website covering the external sculpture of the Louvre|accessdate=21 January 2015}}</ref> The Musée d'Orsay hold the plaster model of "La Chasse".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musee-orsay.fr/fr/collections/catalogue-des-oeuvres/notice.html?no_cache=1&nnumid=088950&cHash=845c7bf363 |title=La Chasse|accessdate=21 January 2015}}</ref>
==[[Wallace Fountains]]== Lebourg is arguably best known for his [[caryatid]]s for the famous cast-iron [[Wallace fountain]], a public drinking fountain seen all over France and in many parts of the world. They are named after the Englishman Richard Wallace, who financed their construction. A great aesthetic success, they are recognized worldwide as one of the symbols of Paris. A Wallace Fountain can be seen outside the Wallace Collection in London, the gallery that houses the works of art collected by Sir Richard Wallace and the first four Marquesses of Hertford. The caryatids depict '''"La Simplicité"''', '''"La Bonté"''', '''"La Sobriété"''' and '''"La Charite"''' as shown below. <gallery mode="packed" heights="200" caption="The four cariatides of the Wallace fountain> File:Cariatide Wallace 1.jpg File:Cariatide Wallace 2.jpg File:Cariatide Wallace 3.jpg File:Cariatide Wallace 4.jpg </gallery>
==17 rue de Châteaudun== As external decoration of this building in Paris' 9th arrondissement, Lebourg created two caryatids. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://cariatides.canalblog.com/archives/p150-10.html |title=17 rue de Châteaudun|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
==Monument to the men of [[Loire-Inférieure]] who died in the 1870 war== [[File:Nantes - Monum morts 1870 05.jpg|thumb|left|400px|Lemborg's Infantryman ("Le Fantassin") stands between Henri Émile Allouard.s " "Le Fusilier colonial" and Louis-Auguste Baralis' "Le Marin"]] This monument stands in [[Nantes]]'s Place Duchesse-Anne. Four sculptors worked on the monument, Georges Bareau, Charles-Auguste Lebourg, Henri Émile Allouard and Louis-Auguste Baralis. Lebourg's contribution was the statue of the infantryman. The monument was erected in 1897 and the inauguration ceremony in April of that year was attended by [[Félix Faure]], Jules Méline, Louis Barthou, Admiral Armand Besnard and Hippolyte-Étienne Étiennez the Nantes mayor. The bronze at the monument's summit, entitled '''"Pour le drapeau"''' was by Georges Bareau and had been cast in bronze by Barbedienne. It depicted a man slaying an eagle and at the monuments base were '''"le Fantassin"''' by Lebourg, '''"le Marin"''' by Louis Baralis, '''"l’Artilleur"''' by Émile Allouard and '''"Le Fusilier colonial"''' also by Allouard. In 1940 the occupying Germans dismantled the bronze believing that the slain eagle could be construed as representing the German eagle but the municipal workers of Nantes delegated to carry out the dismantlement managed to hide the sculpture, so stopping it being melted down. The work was retrieved in 1981, restored and re-erected in 1987. [[File:Nantes - Monum morts 1870 04.jpg|thumb|centre|300px|The Nantes memorial to the Franco-Prussian war]]
==13 boulevard de Sébastopol== There is a Lebourg decoration on the outside of this building.
==Nantes, cimetière Miséricorde== Lebourg executed several medallions for tombs in this cemetery including that of Général Mellinet. <ref name=wkp/>
==Bust of Jean-Marie Écorchard== [[Image:Jean-Marie Ecorchard.jpg|thumb|centre|200px|Bust of Jean-Marie Écorchard]] This bust is in Nantes' Jardin des plantes.
==Monument to Joan of Arc== [[File:Nantes Basilique Saint-Donatien Jeanne d'Arc.jpg|thumb|centre|400px|Lebourg's statue of Joan of Arc in Nantes]] Lebourg executed the equestrian statue of Joan of Arc in Nantes. <ref name=wkp/>
==Lebourg works held in [[Nantes]]'s Musée des beaux-arts==
* '''"Bacchus"'''. This terracotta bas-relief by Lebourg dates to 1877.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=1&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=Bacchus|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
*'''"Bohémienne"'''. This work in plaster was purchased by the museum in 1913.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=2&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=Bohémienne|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* Docteur Guepin. This plaster statuette by Lebourg dates to 1888.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=3&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=Docteur Guepin|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* Docteur Teillais. A bust in terracotta dating to 1885.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=4&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d|title=Docteur Teillais|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref> * '''"Eros"'''. A terracotta bas-relief acquired in 1892.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=5&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=Eros|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* '''"Esmeralda"'''. A work in plaster acquired in 1917.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=6&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=Esmeralda|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* Ferdinand Favre. This study of an ex mayor of Nantes dates to 1892.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=7&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=Ferdinand Favre|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* '''"Joyeux devis"''', This bronze was acquired in 1892.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=9&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=Joyeux devis|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* Jules Elie Delaunay. This bronze bust was executed by Lebourg in 1894. Shown at the 1895 Salon. <ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=10&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=Jules Elie Delaunay|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* '''"La Prêtresse d'Eleusis"'''. This marble piece dates to 1874 and is one of Lebourg's best known pieces. It was shown at the 1874 Salon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=11&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=La Prêtresse d'Eleusis|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* '''"Le Tueur d'aigles"'''. A plaster statue dating to 1893.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=12&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=Le Tueur d'aigles|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* M.Thomas Maisonneuve. A bronze acquired in 1939.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=13&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=M. Thomas Maisonneuve|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* Madame Lebourg. This plaster study of his wife dates to 1899.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=14&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=Madame Lebourg|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* Main de femme. This bronze study of a hand was acquired in 1910.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=15&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=Main de femme|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* '''"Mycias"''', A terracotta work acquired in 1929.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=16&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=Mycias|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* Portrait d'Elie Delaunay. A plaster bust.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=17&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=Portrait d'Elie Delaunay|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* Portrait de femme. A marble bust acquired in 1892.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=18&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=Portrait de femme|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* Ange Guépin. An 1889 plaster work depicting Ange Guépin who was professor of medicine at Nantes. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&FIELD_98=AUTR&VALUE_98=LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste&NUMBER=19&GRP=0&REQ=%28%28LEBOURG%20Charles%20Auguste%29%20%3aAUTR%20%29&USRNAME=nobody&USRPWD=4%24%2534P&SPEC=3&SYN=1&IMLY=&MAX1=1&MAX2=1&MAX3=100&DOM=All%5d |title=Ange Guépin|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* '''"Enfant nègre jouant avec un lézard"'''. This 1853 work was cast in bronze by Butte et Laurent. Shown at the 1853 Salon. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gros-delettrez.com/html/fiche.jsp?id=1664940&np=2&lng=fr&npp=20&ordre=1&aff=1&r= |title=Enfant jouant avec un lézard|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref>
* '''"L’Enfant à la sauterelle"'''. This work was exhibited at the 1868 Paris Salon.
==Works shown at the Salon but current whereabouts unknown== '''"Joueur de biniou, dansant la nigouce"'''. A bronze statuette shown at the 1857 Salon.
'''"Vierge gauloise marchant au sacrifice"'''. A work in marble shown at the 1859 Salon.
'''"Une mère"'''. A marble group shown at the 1861 Salon.
'''"Danaé"'''. Statue in plaster also shown at the 1861 Salon.
'''"La Folie"'''. Terracotta bust shown at the 1865 Salon.
'''"Jeune oiseleur rendant la liberté à une hirondelle"'''. A bronze statue shown at the 1868 Salon.
Saint Jacques le Mineur. Statue in stone shown at the 1863 Salon.
'''"Le centaure Eurytion enlevant la fiancée de Pirithoüs"'''. A group in plaster shown at the 1868 Salon.
Emile Barrault. Bronze bust shown at the 1870 Salon. Used on the Barrault tomb in Père Lachaise cemetery.
Boissaye. Marble statue shown at the 1873 Salon.
Le docteur Quarante. Bust in terracotta shown at the 1878 Salon.
Emile de Girardin. Bust in plaster shown at the 1880 Salon.
Auguste Comte. Marble bust shown at the 1880 Salon.
A. de Lancey. Marble bust shown at the 1882 Salon.
V. Cossé. Marble bust shown at the 1884 Salon.
M. Lheureux. Bust in terracotta shown at the 1878 Salon.
Théodore Maisonneuve. Statuette in bronze shown at the 1889 Salon.
Dante. A bronze bust shown at the 1891 Salon.
Le baron d’Espéléta. Statuette in bronze shown at the 1893 Salon.
Tête de setter Laverack. A bronze shown at the 1896 Salon.
Mme René de Tocqueville. Marble bust shown at the 1904 Salon.

page.title: Lloyd's Maritime and Commercial Law Quarterly

revision.text:
{{Underlinked|date=September 2017}}
'''''Lloyd's Maritime and Commercial Law Quarterly''''' ("LMCLQ") is a [[Law review | legal journal]] that publishes articles relating to commercial law and shipping law. It is currently edited by Professor Sir Francis Rose of the University of Southampton.<ref>http://www.informaprofessional.com/publications/journal/lloyds_maritime_and_commercial_law_quarterly</ref> The LMCLQ was established in 1974. The legal research repository [[Hein Online]] has described the journal as bringing its readership "in-depth discussion of current commercial law topics by some of the world’s leading legal thinkers." <ref>https://www.wshein.com/catalog/104920</ref> It is considered one of the "world's leading journals" in the area of maritime and commercial law.<ref>http://www.bristol.ac.uk/law/research/researchprofiles/rose.html</ref>
As of 2013, it is the most cited English law journal in the world in the field of [[Maritime Law]].<ref>http://lawlib.wlu.edu/LJ/index.aspx?country=All+Countries&subject=International+Law</ref>
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Law journals]]

{{Infobox book | name = Masculinities without Men? | image = File:Masculinities without men.png | image_size = | author = [[Bobby Noble (academic)|Jean Bobby Noble]] | country = | language = English | subject = | published = | pages = | isbn = 0-7748-0997-3 | dewey = | congress = | oclc = }} '''''Masculinities without Men?''''' is a book by [[Bobby Noble (academic)|Jean Bobby Noble]].
==Summary== Noble explores how the construction of [[gender]] was thrown into crisis during the twentieth-century, resulting in a permanent rupture in the sex/gender system, and how [[masculinity]] became an unstable category, altered across time, region, social class, and ethnicity. Noble demonstrates that [[transgender]] and [[transsexual]] masculinity began to emerge as a unique category in late twentieth-century fiction, distinct from [[lesbian]] or female masculinity.
==Reception== ''Masculinities without Men?'' has gotten some significant scholarly notice. However, reviews of the book have been mixed.<ref>{{cite journal|first=Claudia|last=Breger|title=Feminine Masculinities: Scientific and Literary Representations of "Female Inversion" at the Turn of the Twentieth Century|journal=Journal of the History of Sexuality|volume=14|number=1/2|date=Jan–Apr 2005|pages=76–106|publisher=University of Texas Press|jstor= 3704710|doi=10.1353/sex.2006.0004}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first=Donna|last=McCormack|title=Masculinities without Men?: Female Masculinity in Twentieth-Century: Fictions (review)|journal=Journal of the History of Sexuality|volume=15|number=2 |year=2006|pages=333–338|doi=10.1353/sex.2007.0010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first=Madelyn|last=Detloff|title=Gender Please, Without the Gender Police: Rethinking Pain in Archetypal Narratives of Butch, Transgender, and FTM Masculinity|journal=Journal of Lesbian Studies |volume=10|number=1-2|year=2006|pages= 87–105|publisher=Taylor & Francis Online|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1300/J155v10n01_05|doi=10.1300/J155v10n01_05}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first=Sarah|last=Trimble|title=Playing Peter Pan: Conceptua izing "Bois" in Contemporary Queer Theory|journal=Canadian Woman Studies |volume=24|number=2-3|date= |pages=57–84 |publisher= |url=http://pi.library.yorku.ca/ojs/index.php/cws/article/viewFile/6120/5308}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first=Ov Cristian|last=Norocel|title=Romania is a family and it needs a strict father: conceptual metaphors at work in radical right populist discourses|journal=Nationalities Papers: The Journal of Nationalism and Ethnicity |volume=38 |number=5|year=2010|pages= 705–721|publisher=Taylor & Francis Online|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00905992.2010.498465|doi=10.1080/00905992.2010.498465}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
